questions.question_text: What is the difference between RADIUS and TACACS+?

choices.A: RADIUS logs all commands that are entered by the administrator, but TACACS+ logs only start, stop, and interim commands.
choices.D: RADIUS is most appropriate for dial authentication, but TACACS+ can be used for multiple types of authentication.
choices.B: TACACS+ separates authentication and authorization, and RADIUS merges them.
choices.C: TACACS+ encrypts only password information, and RADIUS encrypts the entire payload.

comments.content: Haha Nice! Good way to remember this ;-)
hehe "separated by C" now m never gonna forget this.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
TACAS+ A-Authentictaion | A-Authorization (Both A's are sperated by a C) = TACAS+ seperates Authentication and Authorization.

B is correct answer.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security-vpn/remote-authentication-dial-user-service-radius/13838-10.html

Selected Answer: B
B is correct.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
RADIUS uses UDP while TACACS+ uses TCP.
RADIUS encrypts only the password in the access-request packet, from the client to the server. The remainder of the packet is unencrypted. Other information, such as username, authorized services, and accounting, can be captured by a third party.
TACACS+ encrypts the entire body of the packet but leaves a standard TACACS+ header.
RADIUS combines authentication and authorization.
TACACS+ uses the AAA architecture, which separates AAA.

Selected Answer: B
the correct answer is option B: TACACS+ separates authentication and authorization, while RADIUS combines them. Option A is incorrect because neither RADIUS nor TACACS+ is designed to log commands entered by administrators. Option C is incorrect because both RADIUS and TACACS+ can encrypt sensitive information. Option D is incorrect because both RADIUS and TACACS+ can be used for various types of authentication, including dial-up, wireless, and VPN.
https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/difference-between-tacacs-and-radius/

Selected Answer: C
TACACS+ encrypts only password information, and RADIUS encrypts the entire payload.

comments.content:
TACACS is more secure. Encrypts the whole packet including username, password, and attributes.
RADIUS only encrypts the password.
31 days before the exam, page 179, RADIUS encrypts only the password , TACACS the entire packet

discussion.content:
TACACS (Terminal Access Controller Access Control System) is a security protocol that provides centralized validation of users who are attempting to gain access to a router or NAS. TACACS+ provides separate authentication, authorization and accounting services
RADIUS combines authenticaiton and authorization into a single function; TACACS+ allows these services to be split between different servers.
TACACS+ encrypts only password information, and RADIUS encrypts the entire payload.

comments.content: You got tacacs and radius encryption backwards

discussion.content:
"RADIUS combines authentication and authorization. The access-accept packets sent by the RADIUS server to the client contain authorization information. This makes it difficult to decouple authentication and authorization.

TACACS+ uses the AAA architecture, which separates AAA. This allows separate authentication solutions that can still use TACACS+ for authorization and accounting. For example, with TACACS+, it is possible to use Kerberos authentication and TACACS+ authorization and accounting."

Source: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security-vpn/remote-authentication-dial-user-service-radius/13838-10.html

-TACACS+ provides for separate and modular authentication, authorization, and accounting facilities
-In the Cisco implementation, RADIUS clients run on Cisco routers and send authentication requests to a central RADIUS server that contains all user authentication and network service access information

B is correct
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security-vpn/remote-authentication-dial-user-service-radius/13838-10.html

choices.B: Local AP mode causes the AP to behave as if it were an autonomous AP

questions.question_text: What is a difference between local AP mode and FlexConnect AP mode?

comments.content:
Good link Dave. A is the best answer.

A is an accurate statement as data traffic is tunneled back to the controller for an SSID with Local AP Mode
B should have referenced FlexConnect AP [Standalone Mode], not local ap mode [Central Switching or Connected Mode]
C is wrong as the purpose of FlexConnect is to provide local connectivity when the connection to controller is lost
D is wrong because "local" switching is referenced and it should be "central" switching

https://www.ciscolive.com/c/dam/r/ciscolive/latam/docs/2016/pdf/BRKEWN-2016.pdf

discussion.content:
This link supports "A" as the answer:

"In local mode, an AP creates two CAPWAP tunnels to the WLC. One is for management, the other is data traffic. This behavior is known as "centrally switched" because the data traffic is switched(bridged) from the ap to the controller where it is then routed by some routing device."

https://community.cisco.com/t5/wireless-and-mobility/what-s-the-difference-between-local-mode-and-flex-connect-mode/td-p/2532657

Actually, the right answer is A.
The FlexConnect AP can locally switch traffic between a VLAN and SSID when the CAPWAP tunnel to the WLC is down. If option D had said, "when it is down," it would have been the right answer. But here, they said, "configured."

Selected Answer: D

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/7-2/configuration/guide/cg/cg_flexconnect.html

The question is asking for "the difference" between the two but I believe an access point creates two capwap tunnels when in flex connect mode as well. The only hard difference i see between the two is option "D"
A is the right answer.

A is the correct one
https://community.cisco.com/t5/wireless/what-s-the-difference-between-local-mode-and-flex-connect-mode/td-p/2532657
so we should disregard their answer D ?

ANSWER D
A. Local AP mode creates two CAPWAP tunnels per AP to the WLC
This is not a difference, all lightweight AP modes (not autonomous APs) create two tunnels, one for control and one for data.
B. Local AP mode causes the AP to behave as if it were an autonomous AP
This is not a difference. An autonomous AP stands alone and runs separate code to one that is in lightweight mode. Lightweight mode in "Local" mode transmits as an AP and also scans for noise, discovers rogue devices and performs IDS when not busy.
C. FlexConnect AP mode fails to function if the AP loses connectivity with the WLC
This is not a difference. A lightweight AP in FlexConnect mode can route traffic between a VLAN and an SSID if the CAPWAP tunnel goes down.
D. FlexConnect AP mode bridges the traffic from the AP to the WLC when local switching is configured
This is a difference though poorly worded. See above explanation.
ciao sebastian tu capirai, (bestemmia)

A is correct
n local mode, an AP creates two CAPWAP tunnels to the WLC. One is for management, the other is data traffic. This behavior is known as "centrally switched" because the data traffic is switched(bridged) from the ap to the controller where it is then routed by some routing device.
 
Flex Connect also known as HREAP by the old timers, allows data traffic to be switched locally and not go back to the controller. It basically causes the AP to behave like an autonomous AP, but be managed by the WLC. In this mode, the AP can still function even if it looses connection with the controller. Also, anytime you want to switch traffic locally, that would be the time to use Flex Connect.
correct answer is A
"A" is the right answer!
A is the Correct answer
A is not correct answer
A is the correct answer

comments.content: Excellent breakdown martco and good link. Agree with A

discussion.content:
Answer A - it's the only true unambiguous statement here

assuming a fancy expensive WLC is in the scenario the whole point of Flexconnect mode is to cater for branch/remote office deployment...if you don't want Mary's print job having to "hairpin" the entire infrastructure to get to the printer 6 feet from her desk at the branch office (which is what will happen if u config up the AP as Local mode...the 2x CAPWAP tunnels for DATA (her print job and that nice hairpinning) + CTRL channl all the way back to the WLC in the HQ datacentre. Instead with Flexconnect the AP is allowed to use some smarts and drops the user traffic to whatever port it's hooked to on it's nearest upstream access switch at the branch office (i.e. LOCAL traffic) and you still get to admin the AP remotely over the CAPWAP ctrl channel

but anyways - AP Local Mode = 2x CAPWAP channel 

https://community.cisco.com/t5/wireless-mobility-documents/wireless-lan-flexconnect-configuration-example/ta-p/3112924
A is the answer

D is correct , A isn’t because both create two tunnels , and the question mentioned the “ differences “ , AP in flex mode can works as a local mode if connection failed between AP and WLC or if AP flex mode configured to do local switching.
Thank you guys...it really helped.
A is the correct answer
A is the correct choice

A is not the correct answer. The question asks for the "difference" between the two, and both Local and Flexconnect modes create CAPWAP tunnels.
It's not untrue, it's just not what they're asking.
In FlexConnect mode, the AP has connectivity to the AP's while in Local AP mode, the WLC loses connection to the AP therefore the AP assume the job of WLC and acting as an autonomous AP.
“a” correct answer

questions.question_text: The SW1 interface g0/1 is in the down/down state. What are two reasons for the interface condition? (Choose two.)

comments.content: did you mean D & E? lol

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
A.- When there is a protocol mismatch the status is UP/DOWN
B.- When there is a duplex mismatch, the status is UP/UP
C.- When the interface is shut down the status is ADMINISTRATIVELY DOWN/DOWN

The only 2 answers where the status is DOWN/DOWN are answers C & D

comments.content: Yea I've seen a lot of people bring up the claim and a cisco source claiming it will only impact the performance but mismatched protocol will result in status: down Protocol: down in packet tracer.
But a duplex mismatch takes the ports to in down / down !

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
A. There is a protocol mismatch up/down
B. There is a duplex mismatch up/up
C. The interface is shut down admin down / down
D. The interface is error-disabled down/down
E. There is a speed mismatch down/down

Selected Answer: DE
D & E are correct

protocol mismatch the status : UP/DOWN
duplex mismatch, the status : UP/UP
shut down the status : ADMINISTRATIVELY DOWN/DOWN
speed mismatch = error-disable : DOWN/DOWN

The Down/Down combination can have two interface status:
- notconnect (no cable, bad cable, neighbor device is shutdown, speed mismatch)
- err-disabled (port security has disabled the interface)

Selected Answer: DE
Correct answers are D and E
The interface will be in a down (line Status) - down (protocol status) state (not connect interface) for cases of: No cable, bad cable, wrong cable pinouts, speed mismatch and neighbouring device is (1) powered off (2)shutdown or (3) err-disabled. The interface will also be in down-down(err-disabled) because of port securirty disabling the interface

Selected Answer: DE
Down/Down can be on account of phy problem: no cable attached, sw on other side shutdown, sw powered off, device speed mis match.
If an interface is shut down it will show Admin Down. Not just down so C is wrong

questions.question_text: How will Link Aggregation be implemented on a Cisco Wireless LAN Controller?

choices.A: The EtherChannel must be configured in ג€mode activeג€.
choices.D: One functional physical port is needed to pass client traffic.
choices.C: To pass client traffic, two or more ports must be configured.
choices.B: When enabled, the WLC bandwidth drops to 500 Mbps.

discussion.content:
D is correct

"When you enable LAG, only one functional physical port is needed for the controller to pass client traffic."

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/controller/7-4/configuration/guides/consolidated/b_cg74_CONSOLIDATED/b_cg74_CONSOLIDATED_chapter_010100001.html#:~:text=When%20you%20enable%20LAG%2C%20only,controller%20to%20pass%20client%20traffic.&text=When%20you%20enable%20LAG%2C%20you,on%20which%20it%20received%20them.
This question could be phrased better.

Selected Answer: D
One functional port is needed, with however many non-functional ports 0 to x

Selected Answer: C
Guys, LAG is all about combining two or more physical link and using as etherchannel. There is no way that option D is correct. If there is only one physical channel how it will create etherchannel ?

Selected Answer: D
You can set single-port LAG

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

D is correct
Link aggregation (LAG) is a partial implementation of the 802.3ad port aggregation standard. It bundles all of the controller’s distribution system ports into a single 802.3ad port channel, thereby reducing the number of IP addresses needed to configure the ports on your controller. When LAG is enabled, the system dynamically manages port redundancy and load balances access points transparently to the user.

LAG simplifies controller configuration because you no longer need to configure primary and secondary ports for each interface. If any of the controller ports fail, traffic is automatically migrated to one of the other ports. As long as at least one controller port is functioning, the system continues to operate, access points remain connected to the network, and wireless clients continue to send and receive data.
